description.narrative: The programme works for enhancing children?s rights in Sook, Western Kenya. As a result of cuts in government funding in 2016, the project has faced some replanning. The new project focuses on promoting education and decreasing female gender mutilation in the area. The first secondary school for girls was finished in 2010 and the number of students is growing due to the security provided by the dormitories. The new project phase will keep focusing on making the schools and school environments safe for child ren and girls especially. School drop- out has been very common especially for girls who have been married off often at the age of 12-14 years, right after FGM. The evaluation showed that FGM has decreased by 21 % in the four years of implementation. Now t he percentage of girls who have been cut is 72%. Anti-FGM messages will be spread to children, youth and parents through various partners and media. Women and girls continue making reusable sanitary pads which brings extra income for women and helps the gi rls to participate fully in education. Sook has a population of 22.000 people. The population belong to Pokots and families are mostly nomads moving around with their cattle. The main partner is World Vision Kenya that runs the implementation and accounts for the use of funding.
